title: How to Make Toad in the Hole

methods.name: Making British Toad in the Hole

steps.headline: Preheat the oven to 400°F (205°C).
steps.description:
Make sure that the baking rack is in the bottom third of the oven. {"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/e\/e3\/Make-Toad-in-the-Hole-Step-1-Version-3.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/e\/e3\/Make-Toad-in-the-Hole-Step-1-Version-3.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":307,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":508,"licensing":"

steps.headline: Mix the flour, salt, and pepper in a large mixing bowl.
steps.description: For a more traditional taste, omit the salt and pepper, and use some crumbled up beef bullion granules and mustard powder. Traditional toad in the hole uses fat drippings; the beef bouillon will give you a similar flavor.

steps.headline: Add the eggs and milk, then whisk them together until the batter is light and airy.
steps.description: You can also mix the batter in a food processor or a blender to save some time.

steps.headline: Cover the batter and let it set at room temperature for at least 30 minutes.
steps.description: This will give the batter enough time to set. Covering the batter will also prevent it from becoming too dry.

steps.headline: Coat the sausages in oil, then roast them in the oven, 10 minutes on each side.
steps.description: Pour the oil into a greased, medium-sized casserole dish, then roll the sausages around in it. Bake the sausages for 10 minutes, turn them over using a pair of tong, and bake them for another 10 minutes. The exact size of the casserole dish does not matter, but 8 by 10 inches (20.32 by 25.4 centimeters), 8 by 12 inches (20.32 by 30.48 centimeters), and 9 by 9 inches (22.86 by 22.86 centimeters) are all good sizes to start with. Use good quality pork or beef sausages. You can also use bangers, which are English sausages made from pork and breadcrumbs.

steps.headline: Take the casserole dish out of the oven and increase the temperature to 450°F (232°C).
Pour the batter over the sausages while they are still hot.
steps.description: Swirl it around to make sure that it coats the entire bottom of the pan. At this point, you can also sprinkle the batter with fresh rosemary and thyme leaves for extra flavor.

steps.headline: Put the pan back into the oven and bake for 15 to 20 minutes.
steps.description: The batter should be puffy and golden brown, with the sausages slightly embedded inside. Avoid opening the oven and peeking inside, or the batter will deflate and not rise properly. Instead, turn on the oven light and look through the window on the oven door. If the oven has no window, then simply wait 20 minutes.

steps.headline: Reduce the temperature to 350°F (177°C), and bake for another 10 minutes.
steps.description:
This ensures that the batter is completely cooked through. {"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/4\/46\/Make-Toad-in-the-Hole-Step-9.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/4\/46\/Make-Toad-in-the-Hole-Step-9.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":307,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":508,"licensing":"

steps.headline: Serve the toad in the hole immediately.
steps.description: It tastes great served alongside some onion gravy and mashed potatoes. You can also serve it alongside steamed vegetables instead.

methods.name: Making American Toad in the Hole

steps.headline: Cut a hole in the center of a slice of toast.
steps.description: You can use a round biscuit cutter or a drinking glass. You can also use a cookie cutter as well; a heart or star shape will give you a nice, personalized touch. Use something that is 2½ to 3 inches (6.35 to 7.62 centimeters) wide.

steps.headline: Melt the butter in a skillet over medium-low heat.
steps.description: Tilt the skillet from side to side to spread the butter evenly across the surface.

steps.headline: Place the toast in the skillet.
steps.description: Save the circle (or heart or star) that you cut out earlier. You can toast it later, after you are done making the toad in the hole.

steps.headline: Crack the egg open, and drop it into the hole.
steps.description: Be careful not to break the yolk. Some people find it easier to crack the egg into a cup first, and then pour it into the hole.

steps.headline: Cook the egg for 1 to 2 minutes.
steps.description: After about half a minute, you can season the egg with a dash of salt and pepper.

steps.headline: Carefully slide a spatula under the toast and egg, then quickly flip it over.
steps.description: If you can't slide the spatula easily under the egg part, or if the whites are still too "clear," let the egg cook a little bit longer. If you flip it over too soon, the egg is more likely to break and "escape" the hole. Don't worry if the egg breaks on your first try. It will still be delicious. This technique does take some practice.

steps.headline: Season the other side, if desired, and let it finish cooking.
steps.description: At this point, you can slide the toast and egg across the skillet to mop up any melted butter. The toast is ready when the bread is golden brown, and the egg yolk is set. For an extra touch, add a slice of Cheddar cheese on top of the egg.

steps.headline: Serve the toad in the hole on a plate.
steps.description: If you'd like, you can toast the hole you cut out earlier, and serve it on the side.

Making American Toad in the Hole Cut a hole in the center of a slice of toast. You can use a round biscuit cutter or a drinking glass. You can also use a cookie cutter as well; a heart or star shape will give you a nice, personalized touch. Use something that is 2½ to 3 inches (6.35 to 7.62 centimeters) wide. Melt the butter in a skillet over medium-low heat. Tilt the skillet from side to side to spread the butter evenly across the surface. Place the toast in the skillet. Save the circle (or heart or star) that you cut out earlier. You can toast it later, after you are done making the toad in the hole. Crack the egg open, and drop it into the hole. Be careful not to break the yolk. Some people find it easier to crack the egg into a cup first, and then pour it into the hole. Cook the egg for 1 to 2 minutes. After about half a minute, you can season the egg with a dash of salt and pepper. Carefully slide a spatula under the toast and egg, then quickly flip it over. If you can't slide the spatula easily under the egg part, or if the whites are still too "clear," let the egg cook a little bit longer. If you flip it over too soon, the egg is more likely to break and "escape" the hole. Don't worry if the egg breaks on your first try. It will still be delicious. This technique does take some practice. Season the other side, if desired, and let it finish cooking. At this point, you can slide the toast and egg across the skillet to mop up any melted butter. The toast is ready when the bread is golden brown, and the egg yolk is set. For an extra touch, add a slice of Cheddar cheese on top of the egg. Serve the toad in the hole on a plate. If you'd like, you can toast the hole you cut out earlier, and serve it on the side.

Put the pan back into the oven and bake for 15 to 20 minutes.
The batter should be puffy and golden brown, with the sausages slightly embedded inside.
Avoid opening the oven and peeking inside, or the batter will deflate and not rise properly.

Making American Toad in the Hole Cut a hole in the center of a slice of toast.
You can use a round biscuit cutter or a drinking glass.
You can also use a cookie cutter as well; a heart or star shape will give you a nice, personalized touch.
Use something that is 2½ to 3 inches (6.35 to 7.62 centimeters) wide.
Melt the butter in a skillet over medium-low heat.
Tilt the skillet from side to side to spread the butter evenly across the surface.
Place the toast in the skillet.
Save the circle (or heart or star) that you cut out earlier.
You can toast it later, after you are done making the toad in the hole.
Crack the egg open, and drop it into the hole.
Be careful not to break the yolk.
Some people find it easier to crack the egg into a cup first, and then pour it into the hole.
Cook the egg for 1 to 2 minutes.
After about half a minute, you can season the egg with a dash of salt and pepper.
Carefully slide a spatula under the toast and egg, then quickly flip it over.
If you can't slide the spatula easily under the egg part, or if the whites are still too "clear," let the egg cook a little bit longer.
If you flip it over too soon, the egg is more likely to break and "escape" the hole.
Don't worry if the egg breaks on your first try.
It will still be delicious.
This technique does take some practice.
Season the other side, if desired, and let it finish cooking.
At this point, you can slide the toast and egg across the skillet to mop up any melted butter.
The toast is ready when the bread is golden brown, and the egg yolk is set.
For an extra touch, add a slice of Cheddar cheese on top of the egg.
Serve the toad in the hole on a plate.
If you'd like, you can toast the hole you cut out earlier, and serve it on the side.
